questions.text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and cough. He has been feeding normally and has not had vomiting or diarrhea. The infant was born at term via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immunizations are up-to-date. Eight months ago, he was treated for a urinary tract infection. Four months ago, he had an uncomplicated upper respiratory infection. He is alert and well-appearing. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/56 mm Hg. Examination shows erythematous nasal mucosa. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. After administration of an antipyretic, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supportive therapy and reassurance are indicated to treat uncomplicated bronchiolitis. The patient's vital signs are reassuring and his chest x-ray is consistent with thymic shadow, a normal finding in children < 3 years old. The thymus varies in size and shape and involutes with age, eventually being replaced by fatty tissue.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics would be appropriate if bacterial pneumonia were suspected. Although this infant has fever and cough, the results of his chest x-ray are consistent with a benign finding that is typical of children his age. Apart from symptoms of viral bronchiolitis, he is otherwise healthy; antibiotics are not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest would be appropriate if there were pulmonary or mediastinal findings on chest x-ray that required further characterization (e.g., infiltrate, mediastinal mass). However, the opacity seen on this patient's x-ray is a benign finding that is common for his age. A CT scan carries a large radiation burden and there is no indication to warrant further imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum immunoglobulin levels would be indicated if an immunodeficiency disorder or thymoma were suspected. There is no history to suggest thymoma or immunodeficiency in this patient; UTI and uncomplicated upper respiratory infection are common in healthy children. This infant's normal thymic shadow on chest x-ray is inconsistent with SCID and DiGeorge syndrome, which are typically characterized by thymic hypoplasia.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of T cell count would be indicated if an immunodeficiency disorder were suspected, such as SCID or DiGeorge syndrome. However, there is no history to suggest immunocompromise in this patient; UTI and uncomplicated upper respiratory infection are not uncommon in healthy children. The presence of a normal thymic shadow on this patient's chest x-ray is inconsistent with SCID and DiGeorge syndrome, which are characterized by thymic hypoplasia.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is an invasive diagnostic tool that can be used to diagnose various bronchopulmonary diseases (e.g., suspected malignancy, atypical infection, tracheomalacia, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage). This patient has a fever and opacity on chest x-ray, but is an otherwise healthy child with a short duration of mild symptoms and reassuring vital signs. His radiographic opacity is consistent with a benign finding that is typical of children his age. Bronchoscopy is not indicated.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation suggests uncomplicated bronchiolitis. His chest x-ray shows a thymic sail sign.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a wound in his foot. Four days ago, he stepped on a nail while barefoot at the beach. Examination of the plantar surface of his right foot shows a purulent puncture wound at the base of his second toe with erythema and tenderness of the surrounding skin. The afferent lymphatic vessels from the site of the lesion drain directly into which of the following groups of regional lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The deep inguinal lymph nodes receive lymph directly from the glans penis or clitoris and collect lymph from the superficial inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes. Lymph from the plantar aspect of the foot will eventually drain into the deep inguinal nodes but it would not drain directly into these nodes.

B) CORRECT:

The superficial inguinal lymph nodes directly drain lymph from the skin below the umbilicus, including the lower back, perianal region, and most of the lower extremity with the exception of the posterior calf and the dorsolateral foot, which drain into the popliteal lymph nodes. An infection in the medial and plantar region of the foot, as seen in this patient, can result in lymphadenopathy of the superficial inguinal nodes. Lymph from the superficial inguinal nodes would drain into the deep inguinal nodes, which, in turn, drain into the external iliac nodes.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

C) INCORRECT:

The external iliac lymph nodes receive lymph directly from the body of the uterus, the fundus of the bladder, and the deep inguinal nodes. Lymph from the plantar aspect of the foot will eventually drain into the external iliac nodes but it would not drain directly into these nodes.

D) INCORRECT:

The internal iliac lymph nodes receive lymph directly from the lower rectum to the anal canal (above the dentate line), bladder, upper vagina, cervix, and prostate. They do not receive lymph from the skin over the plantar aspect of the foot.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior tibial lymph node is an inconstant lymph node that, when present, is located along the upper part of the anterior tibial artery. Its afferent lymphatic vessels drain lymph from the anterior compartment of the lower leg and its efferent lymphatic vessels drain into the popliteal lymph nodes. It does not receive lymph from the plantar aspect of the foot.
questions.hint: An infection on the anteromedial thigh would also drain into this group of lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of cough, weight loss, and night sweats. He migrated from Sri Lanka 6 months ago. He appears emaciated. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F). Physical examination shows an enlargement of the right supraclavicular lymph node. Chest and abdominal examination show no abnormalities. An interferon gamma assay is positive. A biopsy specimen of the cervical lymph node discloses the causal organism in cells that are positive for CD14, CCR5, and B7 surface proteins. These cells are most abundant in which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary lymphoid follicles are located in the cortex of lymph nodes and contain dormant B cells. CD14 and CCR5 surface proteins are not found on B cells and while activated B cells express B7, dormant B cells do not. B cells express cell surface markers such as CD19, CD20, CD21, and CD40. Tingible body macrophages are abundant in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid follicles but are not commonly found in primary lymphoid follicles.

B) CORRECT:

The medullary sinuses are vessel-like spaces between the cords of lymphatic tissue in the medulla of a lymph node. The medullary sinus contains a meshwork of reticular fibers and is filled with macrophages. Histiocytes, a type of macrophage in the medulla, span a network of pseudopods that filter the sinuses of incoming pathogens. The medullary cords are packed with activated B cells that undergo differentiation into plasma cells. The cortex of the lymph node consists of primary lymphoid follicles (dormant structures) and secondary lymphoid follicles (active structures with germinal centers) and mostly contains B cells. The paracortex of the lymph node mainly contains T cells.
Image Description:

The parenchyma of the lymph node is divided into a B-cell zone (cortex), a T-cell zone (paracortex), and the marrow. The cortex contains primary and secondary lymph follicles with germinal centers, which allow affinity maturation of B cells. At the hilum (concave side), blood vessels enter and efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node. The entering artery and vein branch into a large capillary network. Special high endothelial venules in the paracortex allow for lymphocyte extravasation.

Afferent lymphatic vessels enter through the capsule at many points in the periphery and open into the subcapsular sinus. The cortical sinus runs from the cortex via the paracortex to the medullary sinus, which then drains into the efferent lymphatic vessel.

C) INCORRECT:

The paracortex, which lies between the cortex and medulla of the lymph node, mainly contains T cells. These cells play a central role in the immune response against M. tuberculosis by activating macrophages against the pathogen but do not harbor M. tuberculosis themselves. Furthermore, T cells express cell surface markers such as TCR, CD3, and CD28, not CD14 and B7 cell surface proteins. While some macrophages may be present in the paracortex, they are much more abundant in a different site.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lymph node tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Tissue layers from top to bottom and outside to inside:
– Fibrous capsule (C)
– Subcapsular sinus (S): leads lymph from drainage area into the lymph node
– Cortex (B-cell zone): lymphoid follicles, composed of mantle zone (green overlay) and germinal center (white overlay)
– Paracortex (T-cell zone; T): parafollicular T lymphocytes between the cortex and medulla

No pathologic features are noted.

D) INCORRECT:

The mantle zone surrounds the germinal center in secondary lymphatic tissues such as lymph nodes and primarily consists of B cells. Activated B cells can express B7 but B cells do not express CD14 and CCR5. Instead, B cells express cell surface markers such as CD19, CD20, CD21, and CD40. Macrophages are not abundant in the mantle zone.

E) INCORRECT:

A periarteriolar lymphatic sheath (PALS) surrounds the central artery of the splenic white pulp and primarily contains T cells. T cells express cell surface markers such as TCR, CD3, and CD28, not CD14 and B7 cell surface proteins. Moreover, a PALS is not found in lymph nodes and macrophages are not abundant in this structure.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a spleen tissue specimen (azan stain)

Left: The white pulp (circular areas of brighter red) and red pulp (pale red making up most of the image) of splenic parenchyma are clearly distinguishable. The white pulp is composed of the periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths (PALS; green shading overlay) and the lymph follicles of the spleen (green outline overlay). Arterioles can be seen the center of the PALS (blue overlay).
The red pulp is composed of the splenic cords (pale red tissue) and the venous sinusoids (small white areas within pale red tissue; highlighted at left edge of image with black overlay). Trabecular veins can be seen at the center of the image (blue overlay and black arrowheads).

Right: high magnification of an arteriole with surrounding PALS (green shading overlay). The lumen of the vessel (black arrow) contains the endothelial cell nuclei (red overlay). The other elements of the vessel wall are the media (red overlay) and the connective tissue of the adventitia (blue overlay).
questions.hint: This patient with weight loss, night sweats, a cough, a positive interferon gamma assay, and a recent history of migration most likely has active pulmonary tuberculosis, which is typically caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. M. tuberculosis is ingested by macrophages, which are positive for CD14, CCR5, and B7 surface proteins. M. tuberculosis has sulfatides on its surface that prevent phagolysosomal fusion, enabling it to persist in macrophages.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a Pap smear showed atypical squamous cells. A colposcopy-directed biopsy of the cervix shows evidence of squamous cell carcinoma. The malignant cells from this lesion are most likely to drain into which of the following group of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A paraumbilical node, also known as Sister Mary Joseph's node, is actually a metastasis rather than an LN. Sister Mary Joseph's node is the result of abdominal and pelvic cancers. It occurs in gastrointestinal malignancies including gastric, colon, and pancreatic cancers, as well as gynecologic cancers, namely ovarian and uterine. Although Sister Mary Joseph's node is rarely associated with cervical cancer, it cannot act as the sentinel node of our patient's cervical cancer because it is not an LN.
Image Description:

A 2-cm, well-demarcated, protuberant, round, purple nodule is visible in the umbilicus. The lesion shows central ulceration and an accumulation of fluid can be seen in the umbilical crease.

This finding suggests a metastatic lesion of an intraabdominal or pelvic malignancy, referred to as a Sister Mary Joseph nodule. Blood tests, imaging, and histopathological analyses of biopsy materials are required to confirm the diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Cervical cancer spreads via pelvic lymphatic pathways. Pelvic LN groups that drain the cervix include the hypogastric route. The hypogastric LN chain follows the visceral branches of the internal iliac artery to the junctional LNs between the internal and external iliac vessels and is responsible for lymphatic drainage from the endometrium, cervix, and proximal ⅔ of the vagina. Thus, an internal iliac LN is likely to be the sentinel node of this patient's cervical cancer.

The cervix and other pelvic organs are also drained by the lateral pelvic and presacral pelvic LN pathways, but even paraaortic lymph nodes can be the first site of nodal metastasis.
Image Description:

Lymph is ultimately drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct only drains roughly the upper right area of the body (green), whereas the thoracic duct is responsible for the rest of the body. The deep lymph nodes are not palpable.

C) INCORRECT:

The right supraclavicular LN would not be the most likely sentinel LN of primary cervical cancer. This LN receives drainage from the thorax, commonly acting as the sentinel node to lung cancer, esophageal cancer, and Hodgkin lymphoma.

D) INCORRECT:

An inferior mesenteric LN would not be the most likely sentinel LN of primary cervical cancer. The inferior mesenteric LNs exist throughout the hindgut, primarily draining the descending and sigmoid colon and the upper part of the rectum. The inferior mesenteric LN is rarely a sentinel node for ovarian cancer but not cervical cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

A superficial inguinal LN would not be the most likely sentinel LN in primary cervical cancer. LNs of the superficial inguinal pathway receive lymph drainage from perineal cancers, vulvar cancers, and cancers of the distal ⅓ of the vagina.
Image Description:

Lymph is drained into the systemic circulation via the subclavian veins. The right lymphatic duct primarily drains the upper right side of the body (green overlay). The thoracic duct is responsible for draining the rest of the body.

Testicular tumors do not typically disseminate to scrotal lymph nodes, because the two organs have separate lymphatic systems: testes drain to the para-aortic nodes and the scrotum drains to superficial inguinal nodes.

F) INCORRECT:

The left supraclavicular LN, also known as Virchow node, would not be the most likely sentinel LN of primary cervical cancer. Virchow node receives lymphatic drainage from the abdomen, commonly acting as the sentinel node in gastric, ovarian, testicular, and renal cancers, resulting in Troisier sign.
Image Description:

A swelling is visible at the left supraclavicular fossa.

This finding is due to enlarged lymph nodes and is typical for lymph node metastasis from gastric cancer. It can also be found in other abdominopelvic malignancies.
questions.hint: The lymph node (LN) into which tumor drains first is called the sentinel lymph node. Cancer cells are most likely to spread here first. Sentinel lymph nodes can be identified using the sentinel node procedure.

questions.text: An investigator who is studying a particular primary immunodeficiency disorder performs lymph node biopsies on patients with this disorder and compares the findings with those of healthy subjects. A photomicrograph of the cross-section of the lymph node obtained from a healthy volunteer is shown. The investigator notes that the region indicated by the arrow is absent in patients affected by the immunodeficiency disorder. Which of the following processes most likely occurs in this region?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

T cell activation occurs when receptors on CD4+ and CD8+ T cells bind to an antigen on the surface of an antigen-presenting cell. This binding triggers the initial step of T cell activation and sets the adaptive immune response in motion. This process typically occurs in the paracortex (the area between the subcapsular cortex and the medulla) of the lymph node, rather than in the germinal center, as indicated in the image here.

B) INCORRECT:

Macrophage activation initiates the process of phagocytosis and plays a key role in innate immunity. Although macrophage activation does occur in lymph nodes, it takes place in the medullary sinus rather than the germinal center indicated in the image here.

C) INCORRECT:

Negative T cell selection eliminates self-reactive T cells (T-cells that bind to an MHC of self-origin). This process occurs in the thymic medulla, not in the germinal center of lymph nodes indicated in the image here.

D) INCORRECT:

V(D)J (heavy chain) recombination promotes antibody diversity during the very early stages of B cell and T cell maturation. This process occurs in the primary lymphoid organs (i.e., the bone marrow for B cells and the thymus for T cells), not in the germinal center of lymph nodes indicated in the image here.

E) CORRECT:

Isotype switching (immunoglobulin class switching) changes the type of immunoglobulin produced by a mature B cell, usually from IgM to another isotype (e.g., IgE, IgA, IgG). B cells originate in the bone marrow and migrate to secondary lymphatic organs (e.g., lymph nodes), where they differentiate into mature naive B cells. Mature naive B cells primarily express IgM or IgD immunoglobulin. These cells then differentiate and proliferate in the germinal centers of lymph nodes, where the immunoglobulin class switching occurs. In certain primary immunodeficiency, such as Bruton agammaglobulinemia, hyper-IgM syndrome, and severe combined immunodeficiency, the germinal centers of secondary lymphatic organs are absent.
Image Description:

Activated mature B-cells become either plasma cells or memory B cells. After proliferation and mutation in the dark zone of the germinal center, the activated B-cells (centrocytes) undergo class switching via cytokine stimulation by T-helper cells.
questions.hint: The region indicated by the arrow is a germinal center.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of night sweats, pruritus, and enlarging masses in his right axilla and supraclavicular area for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows painless, rubbery lymphadenopathy in the right axillary, supraclavicular, and submental regions. An excisional biopsy of an axillary node is performed. If present, which of the following features would be most concerning for a neoplastic process?

choices.text: Polyclonal proliferation of lymphocytes with a single nucleus
Abundant lymphocytes in a wide range of sizes and shapes in medullary cords
Preponderance of lymphocytes with a single immunoglobulin variable domain allele
Positive staining of the paracortex for cluster of differentiation 8
Diffuse mitotic activity in secondary follicles
Predominance of histiocytes in the medullary sinuses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polyclonal proliferation of lymphocytes within reactive lymph nodes is a normal response to infection and is not indicative of a neoplastic process. Malignant cells often display atypical nuclei. However, a single, oval-shaped nucleus with an even distribution of chromatin is consistent with a healthy cell.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytes and plasma cells normally occupy the medullary cords and multiply in response to stimulation such as infection. Depending on their stage of development, these cells are of different sizes and shapes, which is known as pleomorphism. This is a benign finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.

C) CORRECT:

B lymphocytes with a single immunoglobulin variable domain allele indicate that these cells are monoclonal, i.e., they all arose from a single progenitor cell. The normal response to infection is a polyclonal proliferation of B lymphocytes with varying immunoglobulin alleles, whereas uncontrolled monoclonal proliferation from a single transformed cell occurs in lymphoid malignancies. T cells, in turn, rearrange their T-cell receptor genes during maturation. The preponderance of a single allele encoding the variable segment of the T-cell receptor is suggestive of monoclonal proliferation.

D) INCORRECT:

CD8, a surface protein found on cytotoxic T cells, is a co-receptor for the T-cell receptor and binds to MHC class I molecules expressed on antigen-presenting cells. Since the paracortex of lymph nodes is normally rich in T cells, CD8+ staining within the paracortex would be a normal finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.
Image Description:

The parenchyma of the lymph node is divided into a B-cell zone (cortex), a T-cell zone (paracortex), and the marrow. The cortex contains primary and secondary lymph follicles with germinal centers, which allow affinity maturation of B cells. At the hilum (concave side), blood vessels enter and efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node. The entering artery and vein branch into a large capillary network. Special high endothelial venules in the paracortex allow for lymphocyte extravasation.

Afferent lymphatic vessels enter through the capsule at many points in the periphery and open into the subcapsular sinus. The cortical sinus runs from the cortex via the paracortex to the medullary sinus, which then drains into the efferent lymphatic vessel.

E) INCORRECT:

Secondary follicles are active lymphoid follicles with a dense mantle zone and a germinal center, in which B cells proliferate and mature in response to stimulation such as infection. Diffuse mitotic activity in secondary follicles is a benign finding and not indicative of a neoplastic process.
Image Description:

Microscopic image of a lymph node (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

The pale germinal center contains centroblasts and centrocytes. The darker mantle zone is composed of mature, naive B cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Sinus histiocytes are macrophages that reside in the medulla of lymph nodes. They are a normal finding and do not indicate a neoplastic process.
questions.hint: Primary neoplasms of the lymph nodes involve uncontrolled proliferation of a single transformed immune cell that normally resides there.
